audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60–75 minutes; 4 focused sections, each with a worked example and practice.
teacher_notes.materials: Projector, timer, mini whiteboards, and printed graphs/tables for quantitative items.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check plus review of practice responses.

learning_objectives: Cite textual evidence that best supports a claim.
Interpret and integrate information from charts and tables.
Determine central ideas and key details.
Draw logical inferences from concise passages.

structure.title: Command of Evidence (Textual)
objectives: Select lines that best support a given claim.
Eliminate statements that are true but irrelevant.

lecture_script.script: For evidence items, restate the claim in your own words and seek the sentence that most directly proves it.
I predict: ‘proof that the expedition faced unexpected cold.’ Then I scan for the sentence that explicitly mentions the cold as an obstacle.
Which option is relevant but doesn’t prove the claim? Hold up your letter.

worked_example.passage: Although the plan was meticulous, the hikers turned back when an early storm froze the trail and blocked the pass.
worked_example.question: Which choice best supports the claim that conditions forced a retreat?

options.B: An early storm froze the trail and blocked the pass.
options.D: The pass is popular in summer.

worked_example.explanation: Option B directly states the conditions that caused the retreat.

practice_set.passage: The curator kept the painting in low light because its pigments, fragile with age, faded under stronger lamps.
practice_set.question: Which choice best supports the claim that the curator prioritized preservation?

options.B: It was kept in low light to protect pigments.

structure.title: Command of Evidence (Quantitative)
objectives: Read titles, axes, and units before interpreting values.
Connect visual data to textual claims.

lecture_script.script: Always parse the figure: title, variables, scale, and trend. Then match the exact claim to the exact data point or pattern.
We’ll annotate a small table and cross-check which option accurately cites the numbers.
If the claim says ‘largest increase,’ what two numbers must we compare? Answer in one phrase.

worked_example.passage: Figure: A table shows year 1 = 40 participants, year 2 = 50, year 3 = 70 in a school science fair.
worked_example.question: Which statement is best supported by the table?

options.A: Participation decreased from year 1 to year 3.
options.B: The largest increase occurred between years 2 and 3.
options.C: Year 2 had the most participants overall.
options.D: Year 1 and year 2 had equal participation.

worked_example.explanation: Values rise 40→50 (+10) then 50→70 (+20); the larger increase is 2 to 3.

practice_set.passage: Figure: A bar chart shows library visits per month: Jan 200, Feb 220, Mar 260.
practice_set.question: Which choice accurately describes the trend?

structure.title: Central Ideas & Details
objectives: Differentiate central ideas from minor details.
Use wording that paraphrases rather than copies.

lecture_script.script: Main ideas explain the passage’s purpose. Details serve that purpose. Prefer options that capture the whole point without overspecifying.
We’ll reject a choice that quotes a detail but misses the broader claim.
Underline the author’s purpose verb and complete the sentence: ‘The author argues that…’

worked_example.passage: Community gardens, beyond supplying produce, build trust among neighbors who meet regularly to plan, plant, and share the harvest.
worked_example.question: Which choice states the central idea?

options.B: Community gardens foster social connections in addition to food.

worked_example.explanation: The sentence emphasizes both produce and building trust-social connections beyond food.

practice_set.passage: The biography notes that early failures taught the artist techniques later evident in widely praised works.
practice_set.question: What is the central idea?

structure.title: Inferences
objectives: Make logical conclusions supported by the text.
Use evidence to justify the inference.

lecture_script.script: An inference is a justified conclusion, not a guess. Ask: If the text is true, what must also be true?
The narrator ‘checks the door twice’; I infer anxiety or caution because the action signals concern about security.
Which choice goes beyond the text? Call it when you hear unrelated claims.

worked_example.passage: Hearing the thunder grow nearer, Lina moved the metal chairs indoors before locking the garden gate.
worked_example.question: What can be reasonably inferred about Lina?

options.B: She anticipates risk and acts to prevent damage.
options.C: She plans to sell the chairs.

worked_example.explanation: She moves metal chairs and locks the gate as the storm approaches-preventive action shows anticipation of risk.

practice_set.passage: When the auditorium lights dimmed, the presenter paused until the last whispers faded, then began.
practice_set.question: What is the most reasonable inference?

options.C: The presenter waited for attention before starting.

unit_check.question: Which step comes first when reading a chart?
Best evidence is the sentence that

homework: Complete one page of textual evidence items; underline the claim and the proving words.
Analyze two small charts; write one accurate and one inaccurate claim for each.
Summarize three short passages with a one-sentence central idea.
